content: The Act may be cited as the "Medical Device User Fee Stabilization Act of 2005" and includes amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The Medical Device User Fee Stabilization Act of 2005 amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act by adjusting device user fees and annual fee setting procedures. The Medical Device User Fee Stabilization Act of 2005 amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act by adjusting device user fees and annual fee setting procedures. In general, fees for the next fiscal year will be published in the Federal Register under subsection (a). The fees for fiscal year 2007 will be based on a premarket application fee of $281,600. The Secretary may use unobligated carryover balances from fees collected in previous fiscal years for fiscal years 2006 and 2007 to ensure sufficient fee revenues are available, maintaining unobligated carryover balances of at least 1 month of operating reserves for the first month of fiscal year 2008. Notification to Congress is required 14 days before the funds are used. Additionally, in subsection (g)(1), the threshold is increased from $30,000,000 to $100,000,000. For fiscal year 2005, the Secretary must meet performance goals if the appropriated amount is equal to or greater than $205,720,000 multiplied by the adjustment factor. In subsection (h)(3), changes are made to subparagraphs (C), (D), and (E) for fiscal years 2006 and 2007. Additionally, "subsection (c)(5)" is replaced with "subsection (c)(1)" throughout the text. The annual reports under the Medical Device User Fee and Modernization Act of 2002 are amended to include additional information for fiscal years 2006 and 2007, such as details on different types of applications, fees paid by businesses with varying sales, and notifications. Section 502(u) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to require reprocessed single-use devices to prominently display the manufacturer's name, abbreviation, or symbol. The Medical Device User Fee and Modernization Act of 2002 now requires reprocessed single-use devices to display the manufacturer's name, abbreviation, or symbol prominently on the packaging or through a detachable label for patient records. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue guidance within 180 days to clarify these requirements. The manufacturer of the original device must display their name, abbreviation, or symbol prominently as required by the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The effective date for this requirement is specified in the Medical Device User Fee and Modernization Act of 2002.
